conclusion: Problem involves a skydiver and a velocity-time graph showing speed from jump to landing.
Graph has time on x-axis and velocity on y-axis with labeled points and velocities from 0 to 20 m/s.
Question asks for direction of acceleration during 0 to 10 seconds interval.
In a velocity-time graph, slope represents acceleration; increasing velocity means positive acceleration.
From 0 to 10 seconds, velocity increases from 0 to about 20 m/s, curving upwards.
Since velocity is increasing, acceleration is positive during this time.
Graph has a red line tangent at different points, illustrating slope.
At t=0, velocity is 0, increasing to around 20 m/s at t=10 seconds; curve is concave up.
Acceleration is positive and possibly decreasing over time.
Initial free fall has acceleration due to gravity, downward.
If positive velocity is downward, then acceleration is positive in the downward direction.
From 0 to 10 seconds, velocity increase suggests acceleration in the same direction as velocity, downward.
After 10 seconds, velocity decreases from 20 m/s to around 10 m/s by 15 seconds.
During 0 to 10 seconds, acceleration is positive, meaning downward.
Graph shows velocity increasing from 0 to 20 m/s in 10 seconds, consistent with gravity.
Direction of acceleration during 0 to 10 seconds is downward.
